questions.text: Shifting fluid sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Exudative retinal detachment

Explanation:

  • Shifting Fluid sign is seen in Exudative retinal detachment
  • Retinal detachment refers to the separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium.

Etiology:

  • Age: most common in 40-60 years.
  • Sex. More common in males (M:F - 3:2).
  • Myopia. About 40% cases of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment are myopic.
  • Aphakia and pseudophakia.
  • Trauma. It may also act as a predisposing factor.
  • Senile posterior vitreous detachment (PVD): It is associated with retinal detachment in many cases.
  • Retinal degenerations predisposed to retinal detachment: Lattice degeneration, Snail track degeneration, Acquired or degenerative retinoschisis, and Focal pigment clumps.

 

Type of Retinal Detachment

Clinical Features

Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment (Option C)

1. Floaters (dark spots) due to rapid vitreous degeneration.

2. Photopsia (flashes of light) caused by retinal irritation from vitreous movements.

3. Gradual visual field loss, initially localized, progressing to total vision loss as detachment spreads.

4. Dark veil/cloud in front of the eye, particularly when detachment reaches the posterior region.

5. Sudden, painless vision loss in large, central detachment.

6. Retinal breaks may be round, horseshoe-shaped, slit-like, or large anterior dialysis.

7. Vitreous pigments (tobacco dusting or Shaffer sign) are seen in the anterior vitreous with posterior vitreous detachment.

8. Old retinal detachment shows retinal thinning, subretinal demarcation lines (high water marks), and secondary intraretinal cysts.

Tractional Retinal Detachment (Option B)

1. Gradual, progressive visual loss

2. Typically painless

3. No associated flashes or floaters

4. Vitreoretinal bands present

5. No retinal breaks

6. Detached area - concave and localized

7. No shifting fluid

Exudative Retinal Detachment (Option A)

1. Painless and sudden or gradual visual loss

2. No photopsia, holes/ tears, folds and undulations.

3. Smooth and convex with pigmentary disturbances

4. Rounded and fixed with neovascularization on the tumor summit.

5. Shifting fluid - changing the position of the detached area with gravity - hallmark feature.

Retinal dialysis (Option D) involves a circumferential tear at the ora serrata, often due to trauma, but it does not exhibit the shifting fluid sign as seen in exudative detachments.

questions.text: In a three-year-old boy, his parents have noticed a progressive decline in coordination over the last six months. During a physical examination, a growth resembling a cauliflower is observed in the left eye, along with leukocoria and the absence of a red reflex. Microscopic analysis of the sample reveals the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Which gene is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Rb gene

The findings of leukocoria, a cauliflower-like growth, and the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology strongly suggest retinoblastoma, which is associated with mutations in the Rb gene.

The question describes a classic presentation of retinoblastoma, which is the MC primary intraocular malignancy in children.

The key features pointing to this diagnosis are:

  1. Age of presentation: Retinoblastoma typically occurs in young children, usually before 5 years of age.
  2. Leukocoria: This is the most common presenting sign of retinoblastoma, often described as a white pupillary reflex.
  3. Fundus examination: A white, elevated mass in the retina is characteristic of retinoblastoma.

Most specific histopathological feature of retinoblastoma is Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, which are rosettes with a central lumen as shown in the diagram below.

Histopathology and Diagnostic modalities for Retinoblastoma

Histopathology
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific)- These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells
  • Homer-Wright rosettes - These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes
  • Undifferentiated tumor cells
  • Areas of necrosis and calcification

Clinical Presentation
  • Leukocoria (60%)
  • Strabismus (20%)
  • Painful red eye (7%)
  • Poor vision (5%)
  • Asymptomatic (3%)

Fundus Examination
  • White, elevated mass in the retina
  • Can be endophytic, exophytic, or mixed growth

Imaging
  • CT scan: Calcification in 90% of cases
  • MRI: Better for evaluating optic nerve and extraocular extension
  • Ultrasound: Useful for initial screening

Genetic Testing
  • RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14

ATP 7B gene (Option B): Mutations in the ATP7B gene are associated with Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder affecting copper metabolism, leading to copper buildup in various organs, including the liver and brain. It does not cause retinoblastoma.

Rhodopsin gene (Option C): The rhodopsin gene is associated with retinitis pigmentosa, a genetic condition causing progressive vision loss, but not with retinoblastoma.

FBN1 gene (Option D): Mutations in the FBN1 gene are responsible for Marfan syndrome, a connective tissue disorder affecting the heart, eyes, and bones, but not retinoblastoma.

questions.text: Which of the listed conditions is associated with the presence of punched-out lesions on the retina?
questions.solution:
• The most probable diagnosis in this scenario is toxoplasmosis uveitis, which is caused by Toxoplasma gondii
  • Toxoplasmosis is caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii and is a common cause of posterior uveitis. It can lead to punched-out lesions in the retina, which are characteristic of the disease. These lesions typically appear as well-defined, round areas of retinal scarring.
  • Fundoscopy shows focal necrotizing retinitis surrounded by a distinctive “headlight in the fog” appearance
  • An immunocompromised person living with cats is a risk factor for toxoplasmosis

 

Toxoplasmosis uveitis:

  • It is a protozoan infestation.
  • Organism: Toxoplasma gondii
  • Definitive host - cats
  • Intermediate hosts - humans
  • Systemic lesions are more common in immunocompromised patients

 

Clinical manifestation:

  • Most common cause of posterior uveitis and focal necrotizing retinitis (90% of cases)
  • Congenital
    • Inactive disease - Healed punched out heavily pigmented chorioretinal scars in the macular area

 

 

  • In active inflammation - “headlight in the fog” appearance due to intense vitritis
  • Acquired
    • Asymptomatic
    • Same as congenital
    • Punctate outer retinal toxoplasmosis

 

Treatment:

  • Quadruple therapy: Pyrimethamine + Sulfadiazine + Clindamycin + Oral steroid
  • Steroid eye drops for anterior uveitis

 

Posterior staphyloma (Option A): This refers to an outpouching of the sclera in the posterior part of the eye, often seen in high myopia (nearsightedness). It typically does not cause punched-out lesions on the retina.

 

Fundal coloboma (Option B): A coloboma is a congenital defect that can affect various parts of the eye, including the retina. It usually results in a hole or defect in the eye structure but does not typically present as punched-out lesions.

 

Congenital Rubella (Option C): Rubella can cause retinal changes in infants born with the infection, but it is more associated with "salt-and-pepper" retinopathy rather than punched-out lesions.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of sudden loss of vision in the left eye for the past two hours in a 58-year-old man who experienced it after his retirement party? The fundoscopic examination reveals a similar image shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CRAO

Explanation:

The given image shows a cherry-red spot. The orange reflex from the intact choroid stands out at the thin foveola, in contrast to the surrounding pale retina, giving rise to a ‘cherry-red spot’ appearance. Sudden loss of vision and cherry red spots are characteristic of Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO).

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO):

Risk Factors
  • Atherosclerosis
  • Age
  • Hypertension/Cardiac Diseases
  • Thrombophilic Disorders
  • Smoking
  • Diabetes Mellitus
  • Oral Contraceptive Pills

Clinical Features

Symptoms:

  • Sudden, painless, profound vision loss.
  • Painful only in GCA: May present with headache, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, and/or pain around the temple.

 

Clinical Signs:

  • Severely reduced Visual Acuity (VA), often to counting fingers or worse.
  • Profound and sometimes total Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD), also called an amaurotic pupil.

Examination Findings

Fundus Examination:

  • Retinal Whitening: Pale and opaque retina, particularly in the posterior pole.
  • Cherry-Red Spot: Bright red area at the fovea due to the contrast between pale retina and underlying choroidal circulation.
  • Cattle Truck Appearance: Segmentation of the blood column in retinal veins.
  • Attenuated Arteries: Narrowed and segmented retinal arterioles.
  • Optic Disc Changes: Pale optic disc over time due to optic atrophy from prolonged ischemia (chronic cases).

Investigations

Fluorescein Angiography (FFA):

  • Delayed arterial filling.
  • Masking of background fluorescence due to edematous retina.
  • Patent Cilioretinal Artery: Area of normal perfusion of a cilioretinal artery supplies the fovea, potentially preserving central vision.

Other Diagnostic Tests:

  • Retinal edema, structural changes, and possibly an embolic plaque within the retinal artery.
  • Cranial MRI or CT.
  • Carotid duplex scanning.
  • Echocardiography.

Management
  • Smoking cessation
  • Ocular massage
  • IOP control agents: Acetazolamide
  • Hyperosmotics: Mannitol
  • Carbogen (95% O2 + 5% CO2) inhalation
  • Nd-YAG laser embolectomy

questions.text: A male patient, aged 18, seeks medical attention due to an eye injury sustained while climbing a tree five days ago. The patient reports experiencing pain, sensitivity to light (photophobia), and redness in the affected eye for the past two days. Upon performing a slit-lamp examination, a lesion is observed as depicted below. Which of the following characteristics is associated with this particular condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Satellite lesion

 

Explanation:

The clinical scenario of pain, redness, photophobia with presence of thick hypopyon following trauma with vegetative matter is suggestive of Fungal Keratitis. Satellite lesions are characteristic of Fungal keratitis.

Fungal Keratitis:

Etiology
  • Causative organism: Aspergillus fumigatus >> Fusarium
  • Predisposing factor: Vegetative matter injury (trauma)

Clinical Features
  • SIGNS >> symptoms
  • Pain & Foreign Body Sensation
  • Watering/ Photophobia
  • Blurred Vision, Redness

Examination Findings
  • Corneal Ulcer: Greyish-white, dry, elevated, rolled-out margins
  • Pigmented Ulcer: Brownish, dematiaceous fungi
  • Feathery Extensions: Finger-like projections in stroma
  • Sterile Immune Ring: Yellow line of demarcation
  • Satellite Lesions (Option D): Small lesions around the main ulcer
  • Hypopyon: Large, immobile, non-sterile, even in small ulcer

Investigations
  • Corneal Scraping: For microbiological examination
  • Wet KOH Mount: Filamentous fungi or yeast-like fungi (Candida)
  • Culture: Sabouraud's agar for fungal culture
  • PCR: For rapid identification of pathogens
  • Corneal Biopsy: For deep stromal abscess or negative cultures

Treatment
  • Topical Antifungal Agents: Natamycin 5%, Voriconazole, Amphotericin-B, Nystatin
  • Oral Antifungal Agents: Ketoconazole, Voriconazole (for severe ulcers)
  • Surgical Management:
    • Repeated Scraping: Removal of necrotic material
    • Cauterization Options: Carbolic acid (100%), Trichloroacetic acid (10%–20%), Povidone-iodine (5%)
    • Therapeutic Keratoplasty: Corneal transplantation

Reverse hypopyon (Option A): Collection of silicon oil in the anterior chamber is reverse hypopyon, usually seen as a complication of Vitreoretinal surgeries.

Dendritic ulcer (Option B): This is not dendritic ulcer as dendritic ulcer is a feature of epithelial keratitis and not fungal corneal ulcer.

Ring abscess (Option C): Ring abscess is seen in helminthic keratitis.

Correct Answer: A) Retinoblastoma

Explanation:

A paediatric patient with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and Histiopathology revealing Flexner-Wintersteiner Rosettes is diagnostic of Retinoblastoma. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosette is an example of True rosette and is a highly specific feature of Retinoblastoma.

 

 

Clinical features and Diagnostic modalities for Retinoblastoma:

Clinical Presentation
  • Leukocoria (60%)
  • Strabismus (20%)
  • Painful red eye (7%)
  • Poor vision (5%)
  • Asymptomatic (3%)

Fundus Examination
  • White, elevated mass in the retina
  • Can be endophytic, exophytic, or mixed growth

Imaging
  • CT scan: Calcification in 90% of cases
  • MRI: Better for evaluating optic nerve and extraocular extension
  • Ultrasound: Useful for initial screening

Histopathology
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific): These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells
  • Homer-Wright rosettes: These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes
  • Undifferentiated tumor cells
  • Areas of necrosis and calcification

  • RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14

 

 

Medulloblastoma (Option B): is a rapidly growing tumor of the brain, is unlikely to present with eye symptoms initially. Histopathology may reveal small round blue cells with Homer-wright pseudorosettes. IHC shows positivity for Synaptophysin+, CD56+, GFAP+.

 

Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option C): presents with acute painful proptosis. Usually seen in boys in the 1st decade of life. Histopathology may reveal small round blue cells with Homer-wright pseudorosettes. IHC shows positivity for Desmin+.

 

Astrocytoma (Option D): Histopathology would reveal Fried-egg appearance of tumor cells, Eye manifestations are unlikely to be seen in Astrocytoma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about Retinitis Pigmentosa?

choices.text:
ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b waves
B) Rod dystrophy > Cone dystrophy
C) Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision
D) Night vision is lost late and rare
Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision
Night vision is lost late and rare

questions.solution:
Night Blindness is the characteristic and earliest feature of retinitis pigmentosa and may present several years before the visible changes in the retina appear.

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa:

  • Retinitis pigmentosa is a dystrophy of rods and cones, initially, rods are affected.(Option B ruled out)
  • Most common hereditary fundus dystrophy.
  • It can be sporadic (40-50%) or hereditary.
  • If hereditary, autosomal dominant is the most common mode of inheritance followed by autosomal recessive (AR). X-linked recessive inheritance is the least severe form.

 

Clinical features:

Symptoms:

  • Nyctalopia (night blindness) (Option D)
  • Peripheral visual field loss
  • Mid-peripheral superior scotoma leads to ring/ doughnut scotoma resulting in tubular/ tunnel vision. Central vision is affected in later stages (Option C ruled out)

Signs:

  • Triad of a pale waxy disc due to consecutive optic atrophy, attenuation of arteries, and pigmentation disturbance in the form of bony spicules.
  • Tapetal reflex: shinning reflex at macula - seen in female carriers of XLR inheritance.

 

Atypical Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Atypical retinitis pigmentosa includes heterogeneous disorders that share clinical features with typical pigmentary retinal dystrophy.
  • Conditions included are:
  • RP sine pigmento - absence or paucity of pigment accumulation

 

  • Retinitis punctata albescens - scattered whitish-yellow spots with arteriolar attenuation, usually sparing the macula.

 

  • Sectoral RP - only inferior quadrants are involved.

 

Investigation of Retinitis Pigmentosa

  • Electroretinography (ERG) is the investigation of choice - reduced scotopic rod in early disease and reduced photopic with progression.
  • EOG- subnormal- absence of light rise.
  • Perimetry: initially small mid-peripheral scotomas which gradually merge and may progress, leaving only a small island of residual central vision.
  • Electroretinography (ERG): There's a decreased amplitude of both "a" and "b" waves.(Option A ruled out)
  • OCT- to identify cystoid macular edema (CME).
  • Dark adaptometry: Dark adaptation time is prolonged.
  • Decreased Arden ratio may be present.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tuberculosis

Explanation:

  • Tuberculosis is NOT associated with ‘salt and pepper’ appearance of fundus among the given options.

Differential diagnoses of Salt & pepper fundus:

  • Prenatal Rubella (Option A)
  • Congenital Syphilis (Option B)
  • Varicella
  • Mumps
  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Leber congenital amaurosis
  • Drugs: Thioridazine (anti-psychotic)

Syndromes associated with Retinitis pigmentosa:

  • Usher syndrome
  • Kearns-Sayre syndrome
  • Refsum’s disease (Option C)
  • Bardet-Biedl syndrome
  • Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome

questions.text: What is the primary mode of dissemination of retinoblastoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Direct invasion

Explanation:

  • Retinoblastoma primarily disseminates by Direct extension to the Optic nerve. Though optic nerve invasion is the primary mode of dissemination, it occurs via Direct invasion. Hence Direct invasion would be the most appropriate answer.

 

Staging and Treatment of Retinoblastoma: (International Classification of Retinoblastoma)

ICRB Stage

Features

Treatment

A
  • Small intraretinal tumors (<3mm)
  • Located >3 mm from the foveola and >1.5 mm from the optic disc

 
  • Laser photocoagulation: Posterior to equator
  • Cryotherapy: Anterior to equator
  • Thermotherapy
  • Chemoreduction (Etoposide, Vincristine and Carboplatin)

B
  • Large tumors >3 mm in dimension
  • Any size tumors located <3 mm from fovea, and <1.5 mm from the optic disc margin
  • Chemoreduction + focal consolidation
  • Plaque radiotherapy

C
  • Subretinal seeds ≤ 3 mm from tumor
  • Vitreous seeds ≤ 3 mm from tumor
  • Both subretinal and vitreous seeds ≤ 3 mm from tumor
  • Chemoreduction + focal consolidation
  • Possible intravitreal chemotherapy for vitreous seeding

D
  • Subretinal seeds > 3 mm from tumor
  • Vitreous seeds > 3 mm from tumor
  • Both subretinal and vitreous seeds > 3 mm from retinoblastoma
  • Chemoreduction + possible intravitreal chemotherapy
  • External beam radiotherapy in some cases
  • Enucleation if poor response to other treatments

E

Extensive retinoblastoma occupying > 50% of the globe with or without:

  • Neovascular glaucoma
  • Hemorrhage
  • Extension of tumor to optic nerve or anterior chamber
  • Enucleation
  • Possible adjuvant chemotherapy if high-risk features

questions.text: What is the condition characterized by painless vision loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Central retinal vein occlusion

Explanation:

The above fundoscopy image given is that of ‘splashed tomato’ appearance and sudden painless loss of vision are classical features of ischaemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). Splashed sauce appearance is characterized by severe tortuosity and engorgement of all branches of the central retinal vein involving the peripheral and posterior retina.

CRVO:

Risk Factors

Age > 50 years (primary risk factor), Hypertension, Diabetes Mellitus, Hyperlipidemia, Glaucoma (increased IOP), Smoking, Hypercoagulable states

Pathogenesis

Thrombosis driven by venous stasis, endothelial damage, and hypercoagulability

Types

Non-ischemic CRVO (Venous stasis retinopathy) (75% of cases)

  • Mild to moderate, unilateral blurring of vision
  • Fundus: Mild venous congestion and tortuosity, flame-shaped hemorrhages, mild macular edema

 

Ischemic CRVO (Hemorrhagic retinopathy)

  • Severe, sudden visual loss, massive venous engorgement, "splashed-tomato" hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, macular edema
  • Marked vein sheathing, collaterals, neovascularization, chronic cystoid edema

Investigations
  • Ocular Exam: Visual acuity, IOP, Slit-lamp exam (NVI), Gonioscopy (NVA)
  • Goldmann Perimetry and ERG: Differentiating ischemic vs non-ischemic CRVO
  • Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA): Assess retinal perfusion
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): Assess macular edema, sub-retinal fluid

Treatment
  • Systemic Management: Control of systemic conditions (hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hyperhomocysteinemia)
  • Medical Treatment: Intravitreal anti-VEGF (e.g., Bevacizumab), intravitreal steroids (Triamcinolone, Dexamethasone implant)
  • Laser Therapy: Panretinal photocoagulation (PRP) for neovascularization
  • Surgical: Pars plana vitrectomy for complications

Complications

Neovascular glaucoma, Neovascularization of the iris (NVI), Vitreous hemorrhage, Proliferative retinopathy, Chronic macular edema

Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) (Option A): Cherry red spot seen on fundoscopy.

Branched retinal artery occlusion (BRAO) (Option B): Focal area of ischaemia due to vascular occlusion of branch of retinal artery.

Branched retinal vein occlusion (BRAO) (Option B): Sectorial superficial retinal hemorrhages are seen on fundoscopy.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 3-year-old boy who has displayed growing clumsiness over the last half a year, has leukocoria, and lacks red reflex in his left eye? After diagnosis, enucleation was performed, and the specimen displayed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes under microscopic examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Retinoblastoma

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of a 3 year old boy having leukocoria, and lacking red reflex in his left eye is consistent with Retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma

  • Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular cancer in children.
  • Symptoms include leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and strabismus (misaligned eyes).
  • Diagnosis is primarily clinical, supported by indirect ophthalmoscopy, orbital ultrasonography, and MRI to assess tumour extent.
  • Histopathology: Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes is a differentiated type of tumor characterized by columnar cells with a central lumen.
  • Biopsies are not recommended due to the risk of spreading the tumour.
  • Treatment depends on tumour size, location, and whether the disease is unilateral or bilateral. Options include enucleation, chemotherapy, and focal therapies like laser photocoagulation.

Incorrect Options

Congenital glaucoma (Option A) is characterized by epiphora, photophobia, blepharospasm, and buphthalmos.

Toxocariasis (Option C) It is a parasitic infection caused by roundworm Toxocara canis that can be acquired through ingestion of contaminated soil or food animals. It can present with leukocoria, strabismus, floaters, eosinophilia, and hypergammaglobulinemia.

Neurofibroma (Option D) are tumors that arise from nerve sheath cells and are often associated with the genetic disorder neurofibromatosis. In plexiform neurofibroma S-shaped deformity of the lid is observed.

questions.text: What is the condition in which the cherry red spot, as shown in the image below, is observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO)

Explanation:

  • The presentation of sudden, painless vision loss with a cherry-red spot at the macula is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).

  • Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO)

    • The central retinal artery is blocked, causing widespread retinal ischemia. Sometimes, if a cilioretinal artery is present, it can continue to supply the macula, preserving central vision even when the central retinal artery is occluded.

Clinical features:

Symptoms:

  • Sudden, painless, profound vision loss
  • Painless, except in GCA: GCA-associated CRAO may present with headache, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, and/or pain around the temple

Clinical Signs:

  • Visual Acuity (VA): severely reduced, often to counting fingers or worse
  • Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD): Profound and sometimes total (amaurotic pupil)

Fundus Examination:

  • Retinal Whitening: Pale and opaque retina , particularly in the posterior pole
  • Cherry-Red Spot): Bright red area at the fovea due to the contrast between pale retina and underlying choroidal circulation
  • Cattle truck appearance: Due to segmentation of blood column in retinal veins
  • Attenuated Arteries: Narrowed and segmented retinal arterioles
  • Optic Disc Changes: Pale optic disc over time due to optic atrophy from prolonged ischemia is seen in chronic cases.

 

Fluorescein Angiography (FA)

  • Arterial Filling: Delayed
  • Masking of Background Fluorescence: Edematous retina blocks normal fluorescence from the choroid
  • Patent Cilioretinal Artery: Area of normal perfusion if a cilioretinal artery supplies the fovea, potentially preserving central vision

Other Diagnostic Tests

Reveals retinal edema, structural changes, and possibly an embolic plaque within the retinal artery and other systemic causes.

  • Cranial MRI or CT
  • Carotid duplex scanning
  • Echocardiography
  • Thrombophilia screening

Incorrect Options:

Central retinal venous occlusion (CRVO) (Option B) occurs when the central retinal vein, becomes blocked. It typically presents with sudden, painless vision loss and may be associated with retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and retinal edema.

Branched retinal artery occlusion (BRAO) (Option C) occurs when one of the branches of the central retinal artery becomes blocked, leading to a localized area of retinal ischemia. The affected area of the retina may appear pale, with associated retinal hemorrhages.

Branched retinal vein occlusion (BRVO) (Option D) occurs when one of the branches of the central retinal vein becomes blocked, resulting in impaired venous drainage from a particular area of the retina. It can lead to retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and macular edema.

questions.text: In which diseases are microaneurysms observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Diabetic retinopathy

Explanation:

  • Microaneurysms are localized outpouchings of the capillary wall that may form by focal dilatation of the capillary wall where pericytes are absent or by fusion of two arms of a capillary loop.

Diabetic retinopathy Clinical Features:

Early NPDR or Background Diabetic Retinopathy

Severe NPDR or Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy
  • Affects small retinal vessels.
  • Earliest sign: Microaneurysm (Option B)
    • Fluorescein angiography (FA): Tiny hyperfluorescent dots.
  • Retinal hemorrhages: Both deep, i.e., in the inner nuclear or outer plexiform layer (dot and blot hemorrhage) and superficial, i.e., in nerve fiber layer (splinter or flame-shaped) hemorrhages
  • Hard exudates:
    • White or yellow waxy patches with well-defined margins, often at the posterior pole, in the outer plexiform layer.
    • FA: Hypofluorescence with dense exudates.
  • Edema is not marked.
  • Increased inner retinal hypoxia: Leads to multiple retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, venous beading, vascular loops, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMAs), and large areas of capillary nonperfusion.
  • Cotton-Wool Spots:
    • Also called soft exudates or nerve fiber infarcts.
    • Result from ischemia, not exudation.
    • Caused by obstruction of axoplasmic flow, leading to swelling and a white, fluffy appearance.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence due to local ischemia.
  • Venous Beading:
    • Indicates sluggish retinal circulation.
    • Typically adjacent to large areas of capillary nonperfusion.
  • Intraretinal Microvascular Abnormalities (IRMA):
    • Dilated capillaries act as collateral channels.
    • Bypass capillary bed and is often seen adjacent to capillary nonperfusion.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence

Incorrect Options:

Retinal detachment (Option A) involves the separation of the sensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).

Uveitis (Option C) is inflammation of the uveal tract (iris, ciliary body, and choroid) and can cause symptoms such as pain, photophobia, and redness.

Glaucoma(Option D) primarily involves increased intraocular pressure, leading to optic nerve damage.

questions.text: All of the following are causes for expanding blind spots, except for...
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B

  • Hypoplasia of the optic disc: Hypoplasia refers to underdevelopment or incomplete development of the optic disc. This condition is present from birth and is characterized by a smaller size of the optic disc. While hypoplasia of the optic disc can lead to visual impairment, it is not typically associated with an expanding blind spot. Instead, it may cause other visual field defects or abnormalities.

Incorrect option: 

Option A. POAG (Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma): In POAG, there is progressive damage to the optic nerve, typically associated with elevated intraocular pressure. This damage can lead to visual field defects, including an expanding blind spot.

Option C. Papilledema: Papilledema is the swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure. It can occur in conditions such as intracranial hypertension, brain tumors, or other causes of elevated pressure within the skull. Papilledema can cause visual disturbances and may lead to visual field defects, but it does not typically manifest as an expanding blind spot.

Option D. Medullated nerve fibers: Medullated nerve fibers are myelinated nerve fibers that may appear as bright white streaks on the retina. They are a benign finding and do not usually cause visual field defects or an expanding blind spot.

questions.text: A patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension underwent fundus fluorescent angiography (FFA) to evaluate his decreasing vision. The FFA yields an image as shown below, which is characteristic of :
questions.solution:
Correct option A

  • Macular ischemia: This is the correct answer. Macular ischemia refers to the inadequate blood supply to the macula, which is the central part of the retina responsible for central vision. An enlarged foveal avascular zone, as seen in the image, is a sign of reduced blood flow and oxygen delivery to the macula.

Incorrect option:

Option B. Macular edema: Macular edema is the accumulation of fluid in the macula, causing swelling and distortion of the central vision. It is not specifically indicated by the image of an enlarged foveal avascular zone.

Option C. Submacular hemorrhage: Submacular hemorrhage refers to bleeding underneath the macula, which can cause sudden and severe vision loss. It is not indicated by the image provided.

Option D. Premacular hemorrhage: Premacular hemorrhage refers to bleeding within the macula itself. It can cause acute vision loss, but it is not indicated by the image showing an enlarged foveal avascular zone.

questions.text: Which investigation is most useful for visualizing the individual layers of the retina?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- Option B) Optical Coherence Tomography

Explanation

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) (Option B):

  • Most useful.
  • Provides high-resolution, cross-sectional images.
  • Allows detailed visualization and measurement of individual retinal layers (e.g., nerve fiber layer, photoreceptor layers).
  • Essential for diagnosing and monitoring retinal diseases.

Fundus Fluorescein Angiography (FFA) (Option A ruled out):

  • Visualizes retinal and choroidal blood vessels.
  • Highlights leakage, non-perfusion, or abnormal vasculature.
  • Does not provide layer-by-layer retinal images.

USG B-scan (Ultrasound B-scan)(Option C ruled out):

  • Uses sound waves; useful when view is obscured (e.g., hemorrhage).
  • Detects gross abnormalities (e.g., detachment, tumors).
  • Resolution not sufficient to see individual retinal layers.

Slit lamp examination(Option D ruled out):

  • Clinical tool for magnified, stereoscopic view of the retina.
  • Good for overall integrity and surface observation.
  • Does not provide cross-sectional, layer-by-layer resolution like OCT.

questions.text: A woman with a history of proliferative diabetic retinopathy presents with gradual vision changes in her right eye. She reports seeing floaters and flashes of light. What type of retinal detachment is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tractional Retinal Detachment

Explanation:

  • A diabetic woman with proliferative retinopathy with gradual visual loss is most likely to be due to Tractional Retinal Detachment.
  • Retinal detachment refers to the separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium.
  • Retinal detachment can be classified into three types:
    • Rhegmatogenous or primary retinal detachment
    • Tractional retinal detachment
    • Exudative retinal detachment

Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment: This is the most common type and occurs due to a retinal tear or break, allowing subretinal fluid to enter and separate the sensory retina from the pigmentary epithelium.

Tractional Retinal Detachment: Results from the pulling of the retina by fibrous or vascular tissue, commonly seen in fibrovascular proliferative conditions like diabetic retinopathy, without a retinal break.

Exudative Retinal Detachment: Caused due to choroidal pathologies or by tumors pushing the retina or fluid accumulation under the retina due to inflammation or vascular abnormalities, without any associated retinal tear or traction.

Type of Retinal Detachment

Clinical Features

Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment
  1. Floaters (dark spots) due to rapid vitreous degeneration.
  2. Photopsia (flashes of light) caused by retinal irritation from vitreous movements.
  3. Gradual visual field loss, initially localized, progressing to total vision loss as detachment spreads.
  4. Dark veil/cloud in front of the eye, particularly when detachment reaches the posterior region.

  1. Sudden, painless vision loss in large, central detachment.
  2. Retinal breaks may be round, horseshoe-shaped, slit-like, or large anterior dialysis.

  1. Vitreous pigments (tobacco dusting or Shaffer sign) are seen in the anterior vitreous with posterior vitreous detachment.
  2. Old retinal detachment shows retinal thinning, subretinal demarcation lines (high water marks), and secondary intraretinal cysts.

Tractional Retinal Detachment
  1. Gradual, progressive visual loss
  2. Typically painless
  3. No associated flashes or floaters
  4. Vitreoretinal bands present
  5. No retinal breaks
  6. Detached area - concave and localized
  7. No shifting fluid

 

Exudative Retinal Detachment
  1. Painless and sudden or gradual visual loss
  2. No photopsia, holes/ tears, folds and undulations.
  3. Smooth and convex with pigmentary disturbances
  4. Rounded and fixed with neovascularization on the tumor summit.
  5. Shifting fluid - changing the position of the detached area with gravity - hallmark feature.

 

Primary or Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment (Option A,D): Often seen in myopic males, presenting with sudden vision loss, not gradual symptoms.

Exudative Retinal Detachment (Option C): Associated with systemic or ocular inflammatory diseases and presents without the classic flashes or floaters.

questions.text: A myopic patient presents with complaints of flashes and floaters. On examination, a deep anterior chamber is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment

Explanation:

  • A myopic patient with flashes (photopsia), floaters, and a deep anterior chamber suggests posterior vitreous detachment with retinal tear. This allows liquefied vitreous to pass into the subretinal space, leading to rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.
  • Key mechanism: Myopia → long axial length → retinal thinning + lattice degeneration → predisposes to retinal breaks. These breaks allow fluid entry under retina → separation from retinal pigment epithelium.
  • Deep anterior chamber in this context is due to elongation of the globe and posterior shift of the lens–iris diaphragm in high myopia.

Clinical Features

Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment

1. Floaters (dark spots) due to rapid vitreous degeneration.

2. Photopsia (flashes of light) caused by retinal irritation from vitreous movements.

3. Gradual visual field loss, initially localized, progressing to total vision loss as detachment spreads.

4. Dark veil/cloud in front of the eye, particularly when detachment reaches the posterior region.

5. Sudden, painless vision loss in large, central detachment.

6. Retinal breaks may be round, horseshoe-shaped, slit-like, or large anterior dialysis.

7. Vitreous pigments (tobacco dusting or Shaffer sign) are seen in the anterior vitreous with posterior vitreous detachment.

8. Old retinal detachment shows retinal thinning, subretinal demarcation lines (high water marks), and secondary intraretinal cysts.

Tractional Retinal Detachment (Option C ruled out)

1. Gradual, progressive visual loss

2. Typically painless

3. No associated flashes or floaters

4. Vitreoretinal bands present

5. No retinal breaks

6. Detached area - concave and localized

7. No shifting fluid

Central serous retinopathy (Option D): Localized serous detachment of the neurosensory retina at the macula, seen in young stressed males; presents with central vision blurring and metamorphopsia, not flashes/floaters.

questions.text: A patient presents with vision problems and has a history of cataract surgery. OCT finding is shown below. What is the syndrome most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
• Irvine-Gass Syndrome, also known as cystoid macular edema (CME), is a condition commonly seen after cataract surgery.
  • The OCT finding typically shows loss of foveal depression, cystoid spaces, and overall retinal thickening, which is indicative of this syndrome.

 

Cystoid Macular Edema (CME)

Etiology:

  • Ocular Treatment Complications: Post-surgery (e.g., cataract extraction, retinal detachment surgery), ocular laser therapy, and topical ocular medications.
  • Retinal Vascular Disorders: Diabetic retinopathy, central and branch retinal vein occlusion, retinal telangiectasia, and hypertensive retinopathy.
  • Intraocular Inflammations: Pars planitis, uveitis.
  • Retinitis pigmentosa.
  • Vitreomacular Traction: Associated with macular epiretinal membrane (ERM) and vitreomacular traction (VMT) syndrome.
  • Systemic Diseases: Includes leukemia, chronic renal failure, and multiple myeloma.
  • Miscellaneous Causes: niacin toxicity , PG analogues (risk factor for development of CME)

Clinical Features:

  • Visual Loss: Initial minimal to moderate vision loss, potentially leading to permanent vision decrease if persistent.
  • Ophthalmoscopy: Reveals loss of foveal contour, retinal thickening, a yellow spot at the fovea, and a "honeycomb appearance" of the macula.
  • Fluorescein Angiography: Shows leakage and dye accumulation in the macular region, with a "flower petal appearance" in late frames.

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): Demonstrates loss of foveal depression, cystoid spaces, and overall retinal thickening.

Complications:

  • Long-standing CME may result in a lamellar macular hole.

 

Treatment:

  • Addressing the Cause: Intravitreal anti-VEGF or photocoagulation for diabetic CME; discontinuing causative topical medications.
  • Topical NSAIDs: Such as ketorolac, diclofenac, or profenac, are effective in preventing and treating CME.
  • Topical/Systemic Steroids: Useful in established cases.
  • Systemic Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors (CAIs): Oral acetazolamide may be beneficial, particularly in cases associated with retinitis pigmentosa.

 

Posner-Schlossman Syndrome (Option A): This involves high IOP and mild uveitis, but is not associated with macular edema as seen in Irvine-Gass Syndrome.

 

Central Serous Retinopathy (Option C): is characterized by "ink-blot" or "smoke-stack" leakage patterns on FFA, and neurosensory retinal and RPE detachment on OCT. CSR typically does not present with the cystoid pattern seen in CME.

 

Elschnig's Pearls (Option D): Clustered, vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells along the posterior capsule.

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the retina are correctly marked?

choices.text:
1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Outer nuclear layer; 3-Inner plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer
B) 1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer
C) 1-Ganglion layer; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-RPE
D) 1-Ganglion layer; 2-Outer plexiform layer; 3-Inner nuclear layer; 4-RPE
1-Retinal pigment epithelium; 2-Inner nuclear layer; 3-Outer plexiform layer; 4-Ganglion layer

questions.solution:
Histology of Retina:

 

 

Layers of the Retina:

 

Layer

Description

1. Pigment Epithelium

Outermost layer with a single pigmented cell layer; adheres to Bruch's membrane; supports neurosensory retina, and reduces reflection.

Subretinal Space: This is the layer between the Pigment epithelium and the layer of Photoreceptors.

2. Rods and Cones Layer

Contains the outer segments of photoreceptors (rods and cones, which are the first-order neurons); rods detect low-light vision, cones manage color and detailed vision.

3. External Limiting Membrane

A porous membrane allows processes from rods and cones to pass through.

4. Outer Nuclear Layer
(Henle’s layer)

Contains the nuclei of the photoreceptor cells (rods and cones).

5. Outer Plexiform Layer

Includes connections between rods, cones, bipolar cell dendrites, and horizontal cells.

6. Inner Nuclear Layer

Made up of the cell bodies of bipolar cells (which are the second-order neurons), horizontal cells, amacrine cells, and Müller cells; and also contains retinal capillaries.

7. Inner Plexiform Layer

Houses synaptic connections between bipolar cell axons, ganglion cell dendrites, and amacrine cell processes.

8. Ganglion Cell Layer

Contains ganglion cell bodies, which serve as third-order neurons; midget cells synapse with a single bipolar cell, and polysynaptic cells synapse with multiple.

9. Nerve Fiber Layer

Composed of ganglion cell axons that form the optic nerve after passing through the lamina cribrosa.

10. Internal Limiting Membrane

The innermost layer separating the retina from the vitreous; is formed by the terminal expansions of Müller cells, serving as a basement membrane.

 

The Neuroglial cells, particularly the vertical Müller cells, bind the retina's neural elements. These cells provide structural support and nourish the retinal tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication of diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
• Diabetic retinopathy is a progressive microvascular complication of diabetes, which can lead to proliferative changes, causing fibrovascular proliferation and subsequent tractional retinal detachment (TRD).
  • This occurs due to contraction of fibrovascular membranes over the retina, leading to vitreoretinal traction and retinal elevation.

 

Complications of Diabetic Retinopathy:

1. Macular Edema:

  • The most common cause of vision loss in diabetic retinopathy is leakage from dilated capillaries.
  • Clinically significant macular edema (CSME):
    • Retinal thickening at the center of the macula.
    • Retinal thickening and/or adjacent hard exudates at or within 500 µ of the center of the macula.
    • An area of retinal thickening greater than or equal to one disc area, any part of which is within 1 disc diameter of the center of the macula.
  • Types: Focal or Diffuse macular edema

  • Diagnosis:
    • Slit-lamp Biomicroscopy: Loss of foveal reflex and macular thickening
    • Fluorescein Angiography Identifies leakage and also diagnoses ischemic maculopathy.

 

  • Treatment:
  1. Anti-VEGF Therapy: Bevacizumab, ranibizumab or aflibercept.
    • Laser treatment should be deferred for 6 months after commencement of anti-VEGF injection.
  2. Intravitreal Triamcinolone acetonide: Reduce macular edema and improve visual acuity.
  3. Photocoagulation:
    • Focal Photocoagulation: Treatment of choice for focal diabetic macular edema (DME) not involving the center of the fovea using diode or argon burns.
    • Grid Photocoagulation: Considered in recalcitrant cases unresponsive to anti-VEGF agents or intravitreal steroids. Burns are applied to macular areas of diffuse retinal thickening, treating no closer than 500 µ from the foveola and 500 µ from the optic disc.

 

 

2. Vitreous Hemorrhage (VH):

  • Seen as blood floating in the vitreous, occluding the view of the retina.
  • Secondary to proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is a cause of severe vision loss in diabetic patients.
  • In PDR, fibrovascular tissue lies flat on the retina or attaches to the posterior vitreous, leading to vitreous traction, retinal separation, and vessel rupture. This is the most common cause of VH in adults.

 

3. Retinal Detachment:

  • PDR causes scars to form in the back of the eye. When the scars pull the retina away from the back of the eye, it's called tractional retinal detachment.

 

4. Neovascular Glaucoma:

  • PDR causes abnormal blood vessels to grow out of the retina and block fluid from draining out of the eye, leading to neovascular glaucoma.
  • Can cause vision loss and blindness.

 

5. Rubeosis Iridis:

  • Neovascularization of iris, is when blood vessels develop on the anterior surface of the iris in response to retinal ischemia.
  • Prone to spontaneous hyphema as the blood vessels are fragile.
  • Treatment: Panretinal photocoagulation with or without intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF.

 

Posterior staphyloma (Option A): Posterior staphyloma is associated with pathologic myopia, not diabetic retinopathy. It involves progressive thinning and outward bulging of the sclera, primarily in high myopia.

 

Retinoschisis (Option B): Retinoschisis refers to the splitting of the retinal layers, commonly seen in degenerative retinoschisis or X-linked retinoschisis, rather than as a complication of diabetic retinopathy.

 

Progressive myopia (Option D): Progressive myopia is associated with axial elongation of the eyeball, typically seen in high myopia, rather than diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the diagnostic investigation for Best disease?

choices.text:
EOG
B) ERG
C) Multifocal ERG
D) Visual evoked potential

questions.solution:
Electro-oculography (EOG) is the gold standard diagnostic test for Best disease.

 

Best disease/ Best Vitelliform Macular Dystrophy (BVMD), also known as juvenile-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy, is the second most common macular dystrophy after Stargardt disease.

  • Caused by mutations in the BEST1 gene located on chromosome 11q13.
  • Bestrophin, the protein produced by this gene, functions as a transmembrane ion channel in the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).
  • Inherited in an autosomal dominant (AD) pattern.
  • Usually begins in childhood

 

Clinical Features:

  • Stages of the disease include:
    • Pre-vitelliform: abnormal EOG, normal fundus in asymptomatic patients.
    • Vitelliform: a characteristic "egg yolk or sunny-side up" macular lesion. The lesions can vary in size and developmental stage between the two eyes.

 

  • Pseudohypopyon: partially regressed lesion.
  • Vitelliruptive: Lesion fragments, visual acuity declines - “scrambled egg appearance”.

  • Atrophic: Pigment disappears, leading to RPE atrophy.
  • Visual acuity - stable early on but declines in adulthood due to complications like choroidal neovascularization (CNV), scarring, or geographic atrophy.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Fundus Autofluorescence (FAF): hyper autofluorescence yellowish material.
  • Fluorescein Angiography (FA): hypofluorescence due to lesion masking.
  • Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT): hyperreflective material beneath and within the RPE.
  • Electro-oculography (EOG): Severely subnormal across all stages (Arden index <1.5).
  • Hallmark- normal electroretinogram (ERG) but abnormal electrooculogram (EOG). (Option B ruled out) (Option A)
    • Best disease progresses through five stages, starting with the "egg-yolk" vitelliform lesion and potentially leading to choroidal neovascularization (CNV).
    • Asymptomatic carriers may show a reduced Arden ratio on EOG, making it useful for family screening.

 

Multifocal ERG (Option C): Multifocal ERG assesses macular function and can show localized dysfunction, but it is not the definitive test for Best disease.

 

Visual evoked potential (Option D): Visual evoked potential (VEP) evaluates optic nerve conduction and is mainly used for optic neuritis, demyelinating disorders, and optic neuropathies. It does not help in diagnosing Best disease.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby, born preterm at 33 weeks of gestation, is brought by parents with complaints of a white pupillary reflex for 2 weeks. CT revealed calcification of the globe in both eyes. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presentation of a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) in a preterm infant with calcification of the globe on CT scan is most likely indicative of retinoblastoma, most common primary intraocular malignancy in children.

The key features pointing to this diagnosis are:

  1. Age of presentation: Retinoblastoma typically occurs in young children, usually before 5 years of age.
  2. Leukocoria: This is the most common presenting sign of retinoblastoma, often described as a white pupillary reflex.
  3. Fundus examination: A white, elevated mass in the retina is characteristic of retinoblastoma.

The most specific histopathological feature of retinoblastoma is Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, which are rosettes with a central lumen as shown in the diagram below.

 

Histopathology and Diagnostic modalities for Retinoblastoma

 

Histopathology
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific)- These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells
  • Homer-Wright rosettes - These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes
  • Undifferentiated tumor cells
  • Areas of necrosis and calcification

Clinical Presentation
  • Leukocoria (60%)
  • Strabismus (20%)
  • Painful red eye (7%)
  • Poor vision (5%)
  • Asymptomatic (3%)

Fundus Examination
  • White, elevated mass in the retina
  • Can be endophytic, exophytic, or mixed growth

Imaging
  • CT scan: Calcification in 90% of cases
  • MRI: Better for evaluating optic nerve and extraocular extension
  • Ultrasound: Useful for initial screening

Genetic Testing

RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14

 

Retinopathy of Prematurity (Option A): While ROP is common in preterm infants, especially those born before 32 weeks gestation, it typically presents with abnormal blood vessel development in the retina.

  • Leukocoria in ROP is usually due to retinal detachment or scarring, not calcification.
  • ROP is stage-based and does not typically show calcifications on CT unless complicated by retinal detachment.

 

Glaucoma (Option C): Congenital glaucoma may cause enlarged corneas and optic nerve damage, but it does not usually present with white pupillary reflex or calcification.

 

Congenital Cataract (Option D): Congenital cataracts can also cause leukocoria, but they typically do not show calcification on CT. Cataracts are characterized by lens opacity and not calcification within the globe.

questions.text: The image below displays the findings of a fundoscopy. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - CRAO

  • Fundoscopy shows the typical features of pale retina and cherry-red spot, and CRAO is the most likely diagnosis in this case. CRAO often presents with sudden, painless, unilateral vision loss, and it is considered an ophthalmologic emergency because of the potential for permanent vision loss.

Risk factors:

  • Atherosclerosis

  • Age

  • Hypertension

  • Cardiac Diseases

    • Atrial fibrillation: promotes blood clot formation, increasing CRAO risk

    • Mitral valve prolapse: this can lead to blood flow abnormalities and clot formation

    • Bacterial endocarditis: causes vegetation that can travel and occlude the retinal artery

  • Thrombophilic disorders

    • Hyperhomocysteinemia: elevated homocysteine levels increase clot formation risk

    • Antiphospholipid syndrome: an autoimmune disorder causing increased clot formation risk

    • Inherited anticoagulant defects: genetic conditions disrupting natural blood clotting regulation

  • Giant cell arteritis (GCA)

    • Inflammatory condition affecting blood vessels, often with severe visual loss

  • Other factors

    • Smoking

    • Diabetes mellitus

    • Oral contraceptive pills

Clinical features:

Symptoms:

  • Sudden, painless, profound vision loss

  • Painless, except in GCA: GCA-associated CRAO may present with headache, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, and/or pain around the temple

Clinical Signs:

  • Visual Acuity (VA): severely reduced, often to counting fingers or worse

  • Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD): Profound and sometimes total (amaurotic pupil)

Fundus Examination:

  • Retinal Whitening: Pale and opaque retina, particularly in the posterior pole

  • Cherry-Red Spot: Bright red area at the fovea due to the contrast between pale retina and underlying choroidal circulation

  • Cattle truck appearance: Due to segmentation of blood column in retinal veins

  • Attenuated Arteries: Narrowed and segmented retinal arterioles

  • Optic Disc Changes: Pale optic disc over time due to optic atrophy from prolonged ischemia is seen in chronic cases.

Fluorescein Angiography (FA)

  • Arterial Filling: Delayed

  • Masking of Background Fluorescence: Edematous retina blocks normal fluorescence from the choroid

  • Patent Cilioretinal Artery: Area of normal perfusion if a cilioretinal artery supplies the fovea, potentially preserving central vision

Other Diagnostic Tests

Reveals retinal edema, structural changes, and possibly an embolic plaque within the retinal artery and other systemic causes.

  • Cranial MRI or CT

  • Carotid duplex scanning

  • Echocardiography

  • Thrombophilia screening

CRVO (Option B) (Central Retinal Vein Occlusion): Fundoscopic findings- Diffuse retinal hemorrhages (often in all quadrants), venous dilation, and cotton wool spots. The optic disc may be swollen, and there may be blood and thunder appearance. This is different from CRAO, where the retina is pale and a cherry-red spot is seen.

Diabetic Retinopathy (Option C): Fundoscopic findings- Microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and hard exudates. These findings reflect chronic vascular changes in diabetes and are distinct from the acute ischemic signs seen in CRAO, which involve retinal pallor and cherry-red spots.

Cystoid Macular Edema (Option D) (CME): Fundoscopic findings- Cystic spaces in the macula, often with focal macular edema. This causes central vision blurring, but unlike CRAO, it doesn’t show retinal pallor or cherry-red spots. CME is more related to macular dysfunction rather than ischemia.

Correct Option A – Retinoblastoma:

Options B, C, and D do not align with the features described in the question.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is not included in the definition of severe Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Looping in all quadrants

Explanation:

Looping in all quadrants is not a criterion in severe NPDR.

Abbreviated Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) classification of diabetic retinopathy

Category

Management

Non-Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR):

No Diabetic Retinopathy

Review in 12 months

Very Mild NPDR

Microaneurysms only

Review most patients in 12 months

 

Mild NPDR

Any or all of the: microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton-wool spots, up to the level of moderate NPDR. No intraretinal microvascular anomalies (IRMA) or significant beading.

Review range 6-12 months, depending on the severity of signs, stability, systemic factors, and patient's circumstances

Moderate NPDR

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA
  • Significant venous beading can be present in no more than 1 quadrant
  • Cotton wool spots commonly present

Review in approximately 6 months

 

Severe NPDR

The 4-2-1 rule; is one or more of the:

  • Severe hemorrhages in all 4 quadrants (Option B ruled out)
  • Significant venous beading in 2 or more quadrants (Option D ruled out)
  • Moderate IRMA in 1 or more quadrants (Option A ruled out)

Review in 4 months

Very severe NPDR

Two or more of the criteria for severe NPDR

Review in 2-3 months
