Central Serous Retinopathy (Option B) is characterized by "ink-blot" or "smoke-stack" leakage patterns on FFA, and neurosensory retinal and RPE detachment on OCT. CSR typically does not present with the cystoid pattern seen in CME.

Retinal detachment (Option C) Defined as the separation of the retinal pigment epithelium from neurosensory retina.

Diabetic Retinopathy (Option D): Typically shows diffuse retinal thickening and other diabetic changes, not the cystoid spaces seen in CME.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about Retinitis pigmentosa?

choices.text: ERG show decreased amplitude of a and b wave
Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision
Night vision is lost late and rare

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Night vision is lost late and rare:

  • Night Blindness is the characteristic and earliest feature of retinitis pigmentosa and may present several years before the visible changes in the retina appear.
  • It occurs due to degeneration of the rods.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B, and C: All these statements are true.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient with high myopia and thick glasses presents with floaters in his eyes. What is the likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Retinal detachment:

  • Muscae volitantes, i.e. floating black opacities in front of the eyes is one of the symptoms in patients with pathological myopia.
  • This is likely due to Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment due to the traction in posterior vitreous detachment.
  • This causes the pigment to disperse in the vitreous cavity. This is called schafer’s sign or Tobacco dust.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Subarachnoid hemorrhage:

  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage causes subhyaloid hemorrhage.

Option C - Vitreous hemorrhage:

  • Vitreous hemorrhage is caused by blunt force trauma.

Option D - Branched retinal artery occlusion:

  • Branched retinal artery occlusion presents with cherry red spot in the retina.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in very severe NPDR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Neovascularization of disc

Explanation:

Neovascularization (such as on the disc) appears only in proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR), which is a more advanced stage of diabetic retinopathy, involving the growth of new blood vessels. Therefore, neovascularization of the disc is not part of very severe NPDR.

 

Classification of Non-Progressive Diabetic Retinopathy (NPDR)

Severity

Definition

Very mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms only

Mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms plus hard exudates, cotton-wool spots, and/or mild retinal hemorrhages

Moderate nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms plus mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities or moderate retinal hemorrhages

Severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Any one of the following (4-2-1 Rule)

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in four quadrants
  • Venous beading in at least two
  • Moderately severe intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in at least one quadrant

Very severe nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy

Any two of the following (4-2-1 Rule)

  • Severe retinal hemorrhages in four quadrants (Option C ruled out)
  • Venous beading in at least two (Option A ruled out)
  • Moderately severe intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) in at least one quadrant (Option D ruled out)

Clinical Features:

Early NPDR or Background Diabetic Retinopathy

Severe NPDR or Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy
  • Affects small retinal vessels.
  • Earliest sign: Microaneurysm
    • Fluorescein angiography (FA): Tiny hyperfluorescent dots.
  • Retinal hemorrhages: Both deep, i.e., in the inner nuclear or outer plexiform layer (dot and blot hemorrhage) and superficial, i.e., in nerve fiber layer (splinter or flame-shaped) hemorrhages
  • Hard exudates:
    • White or yellow waxy patches with well-defined margins, often at the posterior pole, in the outer plexiform layer.
    • FA: Hypofluorescence with dense exudates.
  • Edema is not marked.
  • Increased inner retinal hypoxia: Leads to multiple retinal hemorrhages, cotton-wool spots, venous beading, vascular loops, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMAs), and large areas of capillary nonperfusion.
  • Cotton-Wool Spots:
    • Also called soft exudates or nerve fiber infarcts.
    • Result from ischemia, not exudation.
    • Caused by obstruction of axoplasmic flow, leading to swelling and a white, fluffy appearance.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence due to local ischemia.
  • Venous Beading:
    • Indicates sluggish retinal circulation.
    • Typically adjacent to large areas of capillary nonperfusion. (Option D)
  • Intraretinal Microvascular Abnormalities (IRMA):
    • Dilated capillaries act as collateral channels.
    • Bypass capillary bed and is often seen adjacent to capillary nonperfusion.
    • FA: Focal hypofluorescence

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of sudden visual blurring that lasted for a short duration. He reports that during the episode, he completely lost vision in his left eye for a few minutes and then regained his vision. The patient denies any pain, headache, or other associated symptoms during the episode. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Amaurosis Fugax

  • Given the patient's clinical presentation of sudden, transient loss of vision in one eye, without pain, and the subsequent restoration of vision, along with the description of a curtain-like visual disturbance, is suggestive of amaurosis fugax

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Central Retinal Artery Occlusion: Central retinal artery occlusion involves the sudden blockage of the central retinal artery, leading to sudden and painless vision loss in one eye. However, in this condition, the vision loss is usually more severe and sustained, often leaving the patient with very poor vision or even complete blindness in the affected eye. The sudden and brief nature of the episode described by the patient makes central retinal artery occlusion less likely.

Option C - Central Retinal Vein Occlusion: Central retinal vein occlusion results from a blockage in the central retinal vein, causing a sudden painless loss of vision. However, the presentation of central retinal vein occlusion typically involves a more gradual and painless decrease in vision, without the sudden and transient nature of the episode described by the patient.

Option D - Hypertensive Retinopathy: Hypertensive retinopathy is associated with long-standing high blood pressure that leads to changes in the retinal blood vessels. It can cause symptoms such as blurred vision, but the sudden and transient nature of the episode, along with the complete loss and restoration of vision, is not consistent with hypertensive retinopathy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old hypertensive patient presented with complaints of blurred vision and headaches. On retinal examination, the following findings were observed: multiple flame-shaped hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and disc edema. Based on the Keith-Wagner classification, which grade of hypertensive retinopathy is this patient most likely classified as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Grade 4

  • Grade 4 hypertensive retinopathy is characterized by severe retinal changes including:

    • Flame-shaped hemorrhages

    • Cotton wool spots

    • Papilledema (disc edema)

  • Presence of disc edema distinguishes Grade 4 from Grade 3, which has hemorrhages and cotton wool spots but no disc edema.

  • Symptoms such as blurred vision and headache indicate malignant hypertension often associated with Grade 4.

Keith-Wagner Classification of Hypertensive Retinopathy

Grade Fundus Findings Clinical Features
Grade 1 Mild arteriolar narrowing Usually asymptomatic
Grade 2 Moderate arteriolar narrowing + AV nicking Often asymptomatic or mild symptoms
Grade 3 Grade 2 + Flame-shaped hemorrhages + Cotton wool spots + hard exudates Visual symptoms possible
Grade 4 Grade 3 + Papilledema (disc edema) Malignant hypertension symptoms like headache, blurred vision

Grade 1 (Option A): Incorrect, only mild arteriolar narrowing without hemorrhages or edema.

 

Grade 2 (Option B): Incorrect, involves AV nicking but no hemorrhages or disc edema.

 

Grade 3 (Option C): Incorrect, has hemorrhages and cotton wool spots but no disc edema.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis who is noncompliant with treatment presents with complaints of superior field loss of vision for the past week. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Branched retinal artery occlusion

  • Rheumatic heart disease increases the risk of cardioembolic events, especially emboli from valvular vegetations or mural thrombi, which can lodge in retinal arteries.

  • Superior field loss corresponds to a lesion in the inferior retina, most commonly due to branched retinal artery occlusion (BRAO).

  • BRAO presents with sudden, painless, monocular, partial visual field loss, often in a specific quadrant.

Retinal Vascular Occlusions

Retinal vascular occlusions are among the most common causes of sudden vision loss and are classified based on whether they involve arterial or venous circulation, and whether the central or branch vessels are affected.

Classification of Retinal Vascular Occlusions

Type Subtypes Main Cause Key Clinical Feature
Arterial Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO) Embolism (carotid or cardiac) Sudden, complete monocular blindness
  Branch Retinal Artery Occlusion (BRAO) Embolism to a branch retinal artery Sudden, sectoral visual field loss
Venous Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) Hypertension, glaucoma, hyperviscosity Gradual or sudden blurring, "blood and thunder" fundus
  Branch Retinal Vein Occlusion (BRVO) Hypertension, arteriosclerosis Sectoral hemorrhages, partial visual blurring

 

Pathophysiology

Occlusion Type Pathogenesis
Artery Embolic or thrombotic occlusion → retinal ischemia → inner retinal layer damage
Vein Venous stasis + increased backpressure → hemorrhage, macular edema, ischemia

 

Fundus Findings

Condition Fundus Appearance
CRAO Pale retina, cherry-red spot at macula
BRAO Localized pale retina corresponding to affected artery
CRVO Diffuse retinal hemorrhages, dilated tortuous veins, optic disc edema
BRVO Hemorrhages limited to one quadrant or sector of retina

 

Risk Factors

Systemic Ocular
Hypertension Glaucoma
Diabetes mellitus Optic disc crowding
Atherosclerosis Increased IOP
Rheumatic heart disease Retinal vascular anomalies
Hypercoagulable states —

 

Visual Field Defects

Condition Visual Field
CRAO Total field loss
BRAO Quadrantic or sectoral loss (e.g., superior field loss = inferior retinal BRAO)
CRVO Diffuse loss or central blurring
BRVO Sectoral field defect

 

Management 

Condition Management
CRAO Ocular massage, reduce IOP, hyperbaric O2, treat cause (e.g., embolus)
BRAO Often irreversible; investigate embolic source (heart, carotid)
CRVO/BRVO Control risk factors, anti-VEGF injections, grid laser (for macular edema), PRP (for neovascularization)

 

Central retinal artery occlusion (Option B): Incorrect — causes total vision loss, not superior field loss.

Branched retinal vein occlusion (Option C): Incorrect — usually shows hemorrhages, with less acute, milder symptoms.

Central retinal vein occlusion (Option D): Incorrect — typically causes diffuse blurring and widespread retinal hemorrhages, not localized field loss.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with the curtain falling sign?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Retinal detachment

Explanation:

  • Curtain falling in front of the eye is seen in case of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.
  • Retinal detachment refers to the separation of the neurosensory retina from the retinal pigment epithelium.

Etiology:

  • Age: most common in 40-60 years.
  • Sex. More common in males (M:F - 3:2).
  • Myopia. About 40% cases of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment are myopic.
  • Aphakia and pseudophakia.
  • Trauma. It may also act as a predisposing factor.
  • Senile posterior vitreous detachment (PVD): It is associated with retinal detachment in many cases.
  • Retinal degenerations predisposed to retinal detachment: Lattice degeneration, Snail track degeneration, Acquired or degenerative retinoschisis, and Focal pigment clumps.

Retinal detachment can be classified into three types:

  1. Rhegmatogenous or primary retinal detachment
  2. Tractional retinal detachment
  3. Exudative retinal detachment

Type of Retinal Detachment

Clinical Features

Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment
  • Floaters (dark spots) due to rapid vitreous degeneration.
  • Photopsia (flashes of light) caused by retinal irritation from vitreous movements.
  • Gradual visual field loss, initially localized, progressing to total vision loss as detachment spreads.
  • Dark veil/Curtain falling sign/cloud in front of the eye, particularly when detachment reaches the posterior region.
  • Sudden, painless vision loss in large, central detachment.
  • Retinal breaks may be round, horseshoe-shaped, slit-like, or large anterior dialysis.
  • Vitreous pigments (tobacco dusting or Shaffer sign) are seen in the anterior vitreous with posterior vitreous detachment.
  • Old retinal detachment shows retinal thinning, subretinal demarcation lines (high water marks), and secondary intraretinal cysts.

Tractional Retinal Detachment
  • Gradual, progressive visual loss
  • Typically painless
  • No associated flashes or floaters
  • Vitreoretinal bands present
  • No retinal breaks
  • Detached area - concave and localized
  • No shifting fluid

Exudative Retinal Detachment
  • Painless and sudden or gradual visual loss
  • No photopsia, holes/ tears, folds and undulations.
  • Smooth and convex with pigmentary disturbances
  • Rounded and fixed with neovascularization on the tumor summit.
  • Shifting fluid - changing the position of the detached area with gravity - hallmark feature.

questions.text: What could be the cause of sudden painless loss of vision?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Central serous retinopathy

Explanation:

  • Central serous retinopathy is characterized by sudden painless loss of vision. The other causes of sudden painless loss of vision are as follows:
    • Optic neuritis
    • Methyl alcohol amblyopia
    • Nonischaemic central retinal vein occlusion.

Central Serous Chorioretinopathy (CSCR) (Option D)

  • CSCR is characterized by the spontaneous detachment of the neurosensory retina in the macular region, with or without retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) detachment.

Pathogenesis: Increased sympathetic drive and corticosteroids affect choroidal vascular permeability, raising hydrostatic pressure, and leading to RPE defects and serous detachment of the neurosensory retina.

Risk Factors:

  • Males aged 20-50
  • Type A personality, Emotional stress, Steroid use
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus, Cushing's disease
  • Pregnancy (3rd trimester)

Clinical Manifestations:

  • Sudden painless vision loss (6/9 - 6/24)
  • Relative positive scotoma, micropsia, and metamorphopsia
  • Recurrence in 30-50% of cases

Examination Findings:

  • Mild macular elevation with circular ring reflex
  • RPE detachment (yellow-grey elevations)
  • Absence or distortion of the foveal reflex
  • Subretinal deposits

Investigations:

  • Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA): Shows "ink-blot" or "smoke-stack" leakage patterns.
  • Indocyanine green (ICG): Shows hyperfluorescence due to choroidal hyperpermeability.
  • OCT: Shows neurosensory retinal and RPE detachment.

 

Treatment:

  1. Conservative: Reassurance; spontaneous resolution in 80-90% of cases within 1-6 months.
  2. Laser Photocoagulation: For cases lasting more than 3 months, recurrent cases, and those with permanent vision loss in the other eye due to CSCR.
  3. Photodynamic Therapy (PDT): For severe, sub-foveal leaks, or chronic cases.
  4. Anti-VEGF: Considered if choroidal neovascularization (CNV) develops.

Incorrect Options:

Chemical injuries to the eyeball and acute congestive glaucoma (Option A and B) typically present with pain.

Acute iridocyclitis (Option C) is associated with pain, photophobia, and redness, rather than painless vision loss.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of visual disturbances. He reports that he is unable to see on the left side from the left eye and the left side from his right eye. However, he notices that his central vision remains intact and unaffected. The patient denies any recent trauma or other significant medical history. What is the most likely visual deficit that the patient is experiencing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing

  • This is the correct answer. This condition involves a loss of vision on the same side of both eyes, but with the central field of vision intact. This condition is usually associated with a stroke that affects the occipital lobe of the brain, which processes visual information. The patient's symptoms - inability to see on the left side from both eyes, but with central vision intact - align with this condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Quadrantanopia: This is a type of visual field loss that happens in one of the four quarters of the visual field. But, the patient's symptoms indicate a loss of vision on the left side completely in both eyes, not just a quarter of the visual field.

Option B - Heteronymous hemianopia: This condition involves loss of half the field of view on different sides in each eye. For example, the right half in one eye and the left half in the other. But, the patient's symptoms suggest the same side (left) of both eyes is affected.

Option C - Homonymous hemianopia: This is a condition in which a patient loses half of the field of view on the same side in both eyes. This can occur because of stroke or brain injury. However, the patient's central vision remains intact, which suggests macular sparing.

questions.text: To confirm the diagnosis, what additional investigation should be conducted for a child exhibiting symptoms of night blindness and delayed dark adaptation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - ERG:

  • Night blindness and delayed dark adaptation are characteristic features of a condition called congenital stationary night blindness (CSNB). To confirm the diagnosis of CSNB, further investigation with electroretinography (ERG) is necessary.
  • ERG measures the electrical responses generated by the retina in response to light stimuli and can help assess the functioning of retinal cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dark adaptometry: Dark adaptometry is a test that measures the time it takes for the eyes to adapt to darkness and regain visual sensitivity.

Option C - EOG (Electrooculography): EOG is a test that measures the electrical responses generated by the muscles surrounding the eye. It is primarily used to assess the functioning of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).

Option D -: Retinoscopy: Retinoscopy is a technique used to assess refractive errors of the eye and does not directly evaluate night blindness or dark adaptation.

questions.text: A 61-year-old university professor complains of vision loss in his left eye. He compares the sensation to a curtain being pulled over his affected eye. Additionally, he experienced flashing lights and floaters a week ago. The provided image shows a B-scan of his left eye. What could be the possible diagnosis for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Retinal detachment:

  • The clinical presentation of flashes of light, floaters, and curtain like effect is suggestive of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.
  • B scan reveals the cyst representing vitreous fluid between the neurosensory layer and retinal pigmented epithelium.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Glaucoma: It is a disease that damages the optic nerve, often caused by high pressure inside the eye. It typically causes a gradual loss or sudden loss of vision but curtain like effect is not seen..

Option B - Posterior vitreous detachment Retinal : It is characterized by floaters, flashes of light, and blurred vision.

Option D - Corneal ulcers: They are painful sores on the surface of the eye that can cause redness, tearing, and sensitivity to light.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 3-year-old boy who has been displaying increased clumsiness for the past 6 months, and upon examination, a cauliflower-like growth, leukocoria, and an absent red reflex in the left eye? Enucleation was performed, and microscopic examination of the specimen reveals the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Retinoblastoma:

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor that arises from immature retinal cells in young children, typically before the age of 5.
  • The tumor can present with leukocoria (most commonest presentation), strabismus , or an absent red reflex on examination.
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes is a differentiated type of tumor characterized by columnar cells with a central lumen.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are tumors that arise from nerve sheath cells and are often associated with the genetic disorder neurofibromatosis. In plexiform neurofibroma S-shaped deformity of the lid is observed.

Option C - Retinopathy of prematurity: It may cause retinal detachment and leukocoria but there is no history of prematurity and low birth weight.

Option D - Toxcariasis: It is a parasitic infection caused by roundworm Toxocara canis that can be acquired through ingestion of contaminated soil or food. It can present with leukocoria, strabismus, floaters, eosinophilia, and hypergammaglobulinemia.

questions.text: Identify the marked layer of the retina
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Inner plexiform layer:

  • Inner plexiform layer- is marked in the given image
  • The inner plexiform layer is one of the distinct layers within the retina, and it is located between the inner nuclear layer and the ganglion cell layer. It plays a crucial role in the transmission of visual information from the photoreceptor cells to the ganglion cells as it contains the synapse of ganglion.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ganglion cell layer : Ganglion cell layer is just present between the inner plexiform layer and nerve fiber layer.

Option C - Inner nuclear layer: Inner nuclear layer is present between the inner and outer plexiform layer and contains the bipolar cells, amacrine cells, and horizontal cells.

Option D - Outer plexiform layer: The outer plexiform layer is located between the outer nuclear layer and the inner segments of the photoreceptor cells and has the synapses of axons of rods and cones with the dendrites of bipolar cells/amacrine cells/horizontal cells.

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the histopathological image of retina.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Drusen:

  • Drusen are yellowish-white deposits that accumulate between the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and Bruch's membrane in the retina. They can be seen as small, round or oval-shaped lesions in the histopathological image of the retina.
  • Drusen are a characteristic finding in age-related macular degeneration (AMD), particularly in the early stages known as dry AMD. They are thought to be accumulations of extracellular material, including lipids and proteins, which can disrupt the normal functioning of the retina and its blood supply.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hard exudates: Hard exudates are lipid deposits that can be seen as yellow or white lesions in the retina. They typically appear as small, round or elongated deposits with well-defined borders associated with diabetic retinopathy.

Option C - Cotton wool spots: Cotton-wool spots are composed of accumulations of neuronal debris within the nerve fiber layer characterized by small fluffy whitish superficial lesions that obscure underlying blood vessels associated with diabetic and hypertensive retinopathy.


Option D - Microaneurysms: Microaneurysms are localized saccular outpouchings of the capillary wall that may form by focal dilatation of the capillary wall where pericytes are absent or by fusion of two arms of a capillary loop seen in diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis for a 65-year-old female patient with a prior diagnosis of chronic arthritis, undergoing treatment, who presents with complaints of impaired vision in both eyes and fundus angiography depicted the following finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Chloroquine toxicity:

  • Chloroquine is an antimalarial medication that is sometimes used in the treatment of chronic arthritis. However, prolonged use of chloroquine can lead to retinal toxicity, specifically affecting the macula, which is responsible for central vision.
  • The characteristic findings of chloroquine toxicity include a bull's eye pattern on fundoscopy and increased fluorescence in the macular area on fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) as in the given image.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Bull’s eye maculopathy is not associated with these conditions.

questions.text: The image is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cystoid macular edema:

  • The given image depicts flower petal appearance of the retina around the macula suggestive of cystoid macular edema.
  • The leakage is always radial at macula because accumulation of fluid takes place in the outer plexiform and inner nuclear layers, and the outer plexiform layer at macula is radially placed and is called Henle's layer.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Flower petal pattern is characteristic of cystoid macular edema.

questions.text: At what point would you suggest conducting a dilated fundus examination for a person diagnosed with diabetes on their 45th birthday?

choices.text: When the complains of decrease in vision

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Immediately:

  • A dilated fundus examination is recommended immediately as part of the initial evaluation for a person diagnosed with diabetes because of the delayed diagnosis commonly associated with type 2 diabetes.. This examination allows for the assessment of the retina and blood vessels in the eyes to detect any signs of diabetic retinopathy, a common complication of diabetes.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: What is true regarding retinoscopy using a plane mirror?

choices.text: In hypermetropia the red glow moves in opposite direction
In myopia the red glow moves in same direction
In emmetropia the red glow moves in opposite direction
Done at 1 meter away from patient

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Done at 1 meter away from patient:

  • Retinoscopy is a technique used to determine an individual's refractive error by analyzing the movement of light reflected from the retina. When performing retinoscopy with a plane mirror, the observer typically maintains a working distance of approximately 1 meter from the patient.
  • Procedure:
    • The examiner holds the retinoscope about 1 meter away from the patient.
    • The examiner shines the light beam into the patient's eye while moving the retinoscope back and forth, horizontally and vertically.
    • The reflected light forms a reflex that the examiner observes.
    • Depending on the movement of reflex with respect to the light it can be interpreted as:
      • With the movement: Patient is emmetropic/hypermetropic/myopia <1.
      • A movement against the light: Myopia <1.
      • No movement: Myopia -1

Incorrect options: 

Options: A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: Roth spots are seen in ____________.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acute leukemia:

  • Roth spots are retinal findings characterized by round or oval-shaped retinal hemorrhages with a pale or white center. The whitish element is thought to be composed of coagulated fibrin in most cases.
  • Conditions associated with roth spots are:
    • Acute leukemia.
    • Bacteremia (subacute endocarditis, endogenous endophthalmitis).
    • Diabetes.
    • Hypertension.
    • Anemia.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the commonly used chemotherapy regimen for the treatment of retinoblastoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide:

  • Chemotherapy is the mainstay treatment in most of the cases of retinoblastoma. It involves carboplatin, etoposide and vin­cristine (CEV) are given in three–six cycles according to the grade of retinoblastoma.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - ERG - normal:

  • The electroretinogram (ERG) is a sensitive diagnostic test for retinitis pigmentosa, it is characterized by decreased amplitude of both ‘a’ and ‘b’ waves.
  • Classic examination findings associated with retinitis pigmentosa are:
    • Pale waxy disc.
    • Attenuation of arteries, and
    • Retinal pigmentation disturbance in the form of bony spicules

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Arteriolar attenuation:

  • Arteriolar attenuation is commonly observed in retinitis pigmentosa. Retinitis pigmentosa is a group of inherited retinal disorders characterized by progressive degeneration of the photoreceptor cells in the retina. This degeneration leads to various visual impairments, including night blindness, tunnel vision, and decreased peripheral vision.
  • Classic examination findings seen in retinitis pigmentosa are:
    • Pale, waxy disc.
    • Attenuation of arteries.
    • Pigmentation in the form of spicules.

Incorrect options:

Option B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: What would be the diagnosis for a diabetic patient experiencing an abrupt vision loss, having a visual acuity of 6/60, with a fundus picture provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - CRAO: 

  • The given image shows a cherry-red spot. The orange reflex from the intact choroid stands out at the thin foveola, in contrast to the surrounding pale retina, giving rise to a ‘cherry-red spot’ appearance.
  • Sudden loss of vision and cherry red spot are characteristic of Central Retinal Artery Occlusion.
  • CRAO (Central Retinal Artery Occlusion): CRAO occurs when there is a sudden blockage in the central retinal artery, leading to a severe and immediate loss of vision.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Cherry red spot is not seen in these conditions.

questions.text: Please identify the structure indicated by the arrow.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Choroid

  • The structure marked with arrow is the choroid
  • The choroid is a critical structure in the eye, part of the uveal tract, which also includes the ciliary body and the iris.
  • The main functions of the choroid are to provide oxygen and nutrients to the outer layers of the retina and to absorb scattered light, thereby reducing reflections within the eye.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Outer limiting membrane: The outer limiting membrane is a structure in the retina that separates the outer nuclear layer from the inner segments of the photoreceptor cells. It is formed by the junctions between the Müller cells and the photoreceptor cells. The red arrow in the image does not point to the outer limiting membrane.

Option B - Inner plexiform layer: The inner plexiform layer is a layer of the retina located between the inner nuclear layer and the ganglion cell layer. It contains synaptic connections between bipolar cells, amacrine cells, and ganglion cells.

Option D - Outer nuclear layer: The outer nuclear layer is a layer of the retina located between the outer plexiform layer and the external limiting membrane. It contains the cell bodies of the photoreceptor cells (rods and cones).

questions.text: ETDRS study was related to
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Diabetic macular edema:

  • The ETDRS (Early Treatment of Diabetic Retinopathy Study) study was primarily conducted to study the treatment options for diabetic macular edema, a common complication of diabetic retinopathy characterized by fluid accumulation in the macula.
  • Early Treatment of Diabetic Retinopathy
    • It classifies the diabetic retinopathy into
      • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)
        • No DR
        • Very mild NPDR - Microaneurysm only
        • Mild NPDR - microaneurysms, retinal haemorrhages, exudates, cotton-wool spots
        • Moderate NPDR - Severe retinal haemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA, and venous beading in 1 quadrant.
        • Severe NPDR - One or more of severe haemorrhages in all 4 quadrants, significant venous beading in 2 or more quadrants
        • Very severe NPDR - Two or more of the criteria for severe NPDR.
    • PDR (Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy)
      • Mild-moderate PDR - New vessels on the disc (NVD) or new vessels elsewhere (NVE), but extent insufficient to meet the high-risk criteria.
      • High-risk PDR - NVD greater than ETDRS standard photograph 10A, with vitreous haemorrhage, and NVE greater than 2 disc area with vitreous haemorrhage.
      • Advanced diabetic eye disease - Vitreous hemorrhage, tractional retinal detachment, and neovascular glaucoma.
